The Fundamental Price of Secure Aggregation in Differentially Private Federated Learning

Wei-Ning Chen∗†‡    Christopher A. Choquette-Choo∗‡    Peter Kairouz∗‡    Ananda Theertha Suresh∗‡
(Stanford University†, Google Research‡
wnchen@stanford.edu, {cchoquette, kairouz, theertha}@google.com )
Abstract

We consider the problem of training a d𝑑d dimensional model with distributed differential privacy (DP) where secure aggregation (SecAgg) is used to ensure that the server only sees the noisy sum of n𝑛n model updates in every training round. Taking into account the constraints imposed by SecAgg, we characterize the fundamental communication cost required to obtain the best accuracy achievable under ε𝜀\varepsilon central DP (i.e. under a fully trusted server and no communication constraints). Our results show that O~​(min⁡(n2​ε2,d))~𝑂superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2𝑑\tilde{O}\left(\min(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2},d)\right) bits per client are both sufficient and necessary, and this fundamental limit can be achieved by a linear scheme based on sparse random projections. This provides a significant improvement relative to state-of-the-art SecAgg distributed DP schemes which use O~​(d​log⁡(d/ε2))~𝑂𝑑𝑑superscript𝜀2\tilde{O}(d\log(d/\varepsilon^{2})) bits per client.

Empirically, we evaluate our proposed scheme on real-world federated learning tasks. We find that our theoretical analysis is well matched in practice. In particular, we show that we can reduce the communication cost significantly to under 1.21.21.2 bits per parameter in realistic privacy settings without decreasing test-time performance. Our work hence theoretically and empirically specifies the fundamental price of using SecAgg. ††footnotetext: * Equal contribution with alphabetical authorship. †Work completed while on internship at Google.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a widely used machine learning framework where multiple clients collaborate in learning a model under the coordination of a central server (McMahan et al., 2017a; Kairouz et al., 2021b). One of the primary attractions of FL is that it provides data confidentiality and can provide a level of privacy to participating clients through data minimization: the raw client data never leaves the device, and only updates to models (e.g., gradient updates) are sent back to the central server. This provides practical privacy improvements over centralized settings because updates typically contain less information about the clients, because they are more focused on the learning task, and also only need to be held ephemerally by the server

However, this vanilla federated learning does not provide any formal or provable privacy guarantees. To do so, FL is often combined with differential privacy (DP) (Dwork et al., 2006b). This can be done in one of two ways111Local DP is yet another alternative, but it incurs higher utility loss and is therefore not typically used in practice.: 1) perturbing the aggregated (local) model updates at the server before updating the global model, or 2) perturbing each client’s model update locally and using a cryptographic multi-party computation protocol to ensure that the server only sees the noisy aggregate. The former is referred to as central DP, and it relies on the clients’ trust in the server because any sensitive information contained in the model updates is revealed to and temporally stored on the server. The latter is referred to as distributed DP (Dwork et al., 2006a; Kairouz et al., 2021a; Agarwal et al., 2021, 2018), and it offers privacy guarantees with respect to an honest-but-curious server. Thus, a key technology for formalizing and strengthening FL’s privacy guarantees is a secure vector sum protocol called secure aggregation (SecAgg) (Bonawitz et al., 2016; Bell et al., 2020), which lets the server see the aggregate client updates but not the individual ones.

Despite enhancing the clients’ privacy, aggregating model updates via SecAgg drastically increases the computation and communication overheads (Bonawitz et al., 2016, 2019). This is even worse in federated settings where communication occurs over bandwidth-limited wireless links, and the extra communication costs may become a bottleneck that hampers efficient training of large-scale machine learning models. For example, Kairouz et al. (2021a) reports that when training a language model with SecAgg and DP, even with a carefully designed quantization scheme, each client still needs to transmit about 161616 bits per model parameter each round. Moreover, the bitwidth needs to be scaled up when the privacy requirements are more stringent. This behavior disobeys the conclusion of Chen et al. (2020) (derived under local DP), which shows that the optimal communication cost should decay with the privacy budget, i.e., data is more compressible in the high privacy regime.

Furthermore, because the server aggregates the model updates via SecAgg, we can only compress the model updates locally using linear schemes. This constraint rules out many popular compression schemes such as entropy encoders or gradient sparsification (Aji & Heafield, 2017; Lin et al., 2017; Wangni et al., 2017; Havasi et al., 2018; Oktay et al., 2019) etc., as these methods are non-linear.

Therefore, it is unclear whether or not the communication cost of SecAgg reported in Kairouz et al. (2021a); Agarwal et al. (2021, 2018) is fundamental. If not, what is the smallest communication needed to achieve distributed DP with secure aggregation to achieve the same performance as in the centralized DP setting?

In this paper, we answer the above question, showing that the communication costs of existing mechanisms are strictly sub-optimal in the distributed mean estimation (DME) task (Suresh et al., 2017) (see Section 4 for details). We also propose a SecAgg comaptible linear compression scheme based on sparse random projections (Algorithm 2), and then combine it with the distributed discrete Gaussian (DDG) mechanism proposed by Kairouz et al. (2021a). Theoretically, we prove that our scheme requires O~​(min⁡(n2​ε2,d))~𝑂superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2𝑑\tilde{O}\left(\min(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2},d)\right) bits per client, where n𝑛n is the per-round number of clients. This cost is significantly smaller than the communication cost of previous schemes which was O~δ​(d​log⁡(d/ε2))subscript~𝑂𝛿𝑑𝑑superscript𝜀2\tilde{O}_{\delta}(d\log(d/\varepsilon^{2})) bits per client222For simplicity, we use the O~δ​(⋅)subscript~𝑂𝛿⋅\tilde{O}_{\delta}\left(\cdot\right) notation to hide the dependency on δ𝛿\delta and log⁡n𝑛\log n. To give perspective, (1) n𝑛n is usually on the order of 103superscript10310^{3} per round due to the computational overhead of SecAgg, and (2) ε𝜀\varepsilon is the privacy budget for a single round, i.e., ε≈ε𝖿𝗂𝗇𝖺𝗅/R𝜀subscript𝜀𝖿𝗂𝗇𝖺𝗅𝑅\varepsilon\approx{\varepsilon_{\mathsf{final}}}/{\sqrt{R}} if there are R𝑅R training rounds. Thus, for practical FL settings where large models are trained with SecAgg over many rounds, n2​ε2superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2n^{2}\varepsilon^{2} is typically (much) smaller than d𝑑d.

We complement our achievability results with a matching lower bound, showing that to obtain an unbiased estimator of the mean vector, each client needs to communicate Ω~​(min⁡(n2​ε2,d))~Ωsuperscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2𝑑\tilde{\Omega}(\min(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2},d)) bits with the server. Our upper and lower bounds together specify the fundamental privacy-communication-accuracy trade-offs under SecAgg and DP.

In addition, we show that with additional sparsity assumptions, we can further improve both the accuracy and communication efficiency while achieving the same privacy requirement, leading to a logarithmic dependency on d𝑑d.

Empirically, we verify our scheme on a variety of real-world FL tasks. Compared to existing distributed DP schemes, we observe 101010x or more compression with no significant decrease in test-time performance. Moreover, the compression rates can be made even higher with tighter privacy constraints (i.e., with smaller ε𝜀\varepsilon), complying with our theoretical O~(min(n2ε2,d)\tilde{O}(\min(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2},d) communication bound.

Organization

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. We summarize related work in Section 2 and introduce necessary preliminaries in Section 3. We then provide a formal problem formulation in Section 4. Next, we present and analyze the performance of our main scheme (in terms of privacy, utility, and communication efficiency) and prove its optimality in Section 5.5. After that, we show, in Section 6.2, that with additional sparsity assumptions, one can simultaneously reduce the communication cost and increase the accuracy. Finally, we present our experimental results in Section 7 and conclude the paper in Section 8.

2 Related Work

SecAgg and distributed DP

SecAgg is cryptographic secure multi-party computation (MPC) that allows the server to collect the sum of n𝑛n vectors from clients without knowing anyone of them. In our single-server FL setting, SecAgg is achieved via additive masking over a finite group (Bonawitz et al., 2016; Bell et al., 2020). However, the vanilla FL with SecAgg does not provide provable privacy guarantees since the sum of updates may still leak sensitive information (Melis et al., 2019; Song & Shmatikov, 2019; Carlini et al., 2019; Shokri et al., 2017). To address this issue, differential privacy (DP) (Dwork et al., 2006a), and in particular, DP-SGD or DP-FedAvg can be employed Song et al. (2013); Bassily et al. (2014); Geyer et al. (2017); McMahan et al. (2017b). In this work, we aim to provide privacy guarantees in the form of Rényi DP (Mironov, 2017) because it allows for accounting end-to-end privacy loss tightly.

We also distinguish our setup from the local DP setting (Kasiviswanathan et al., 2011; Evfimievski et al., 2004; Warner, 1965), where the data is perturbed on the client-side before it is collected by the server. Local DP, which allows for a possibly malicious server, is stronger than distributed DP, which assumes an honest-but-curious server. Thus, local DP suffers from worse privacy-utility tarde-offs (Kasiviswanathan et al., 2011; Duchi et al., 2013; Kairouz et al., 2016).

Model compression, sketching, and random projection

There has been a significant amount of recent work on reducing the communication cost in FL, see Kairouz et al. (2019). Among them, popular compression approaches include gradient quantization (Alistarh et al., 2017; Bernstein et al., 2018), sparsification (Aji & Heafield, 2017; Lin et al., 2017; Wangni et al., 2017), and entropy encoders (Havasi et al., 2018; Oktay et al., 2019). However, since these schemes are mostly non-linear, they cannot be combined with SecAgg where all the encoded messages will be summed together. Therefore, in this work, we resort to compression schemes with linear encoders. The only exception are sketching based methods (Rothchild et al., 2020; Haddadpour et al., 2020). Our work differs from them in three aspects. First, we consider FL with privacy and SecAgg, whereas Rothchild et al. (2020) only aims at reducing communication. Second, although we use the same count-sketch encoder, our decoding method is more aligned with the sparse random projection (Kane & Nelson, 2014). In the language of sketching, we decode the sketched model updates by “count-mean” instead of count-median, which improves space efficiency, thus requiring less memory to train a real-world large-scale machine learning model. We note that both count-sketch and random projection provides the same worst-case ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} error bounds.

FL with SecAgg and distributed DP

The closest works to ours are cpSGD (Agarwal et al., 2018), DDG (Kairouz et al., 2021a), and Skellam (Agarwal et al., 2021), which serve as the main inspiration of this paper. However, all of these methods rely on per parameter quantization and thus lead to Ω~​(d)~Ω𝑑\tilde{\Omega}\left(d\right) communication cost. In this work, however, we show that when d≫n2​ε2much-greater-than𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2d\gg n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}, we can further reduce dimensionality and achieve the optimal communication cost O~​(n2​ε2)~𝑂superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2\tilde{O}(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}) in this regime. Our scheme also demonstrates 101010x or more compression rates (depending on the privacy budget) relative to the best existing distributed DP schemes.

3 Preliminaries

3.1 Differential Privacy

We begin by providing a formal definition for (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differential privacy (DP) Dwork et al. (2006b).

Definition 3.1 (Differential Privacy).

For ε,δ≥0𝜀𝛿0\varepsilon,\delta\geq 0, a randomized mechanism M𝑀M satisfies (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP if for all neighboring datasets D,D′𝐷superscript𝐷′D,D^{\prime} and all 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} in the range of M𝑀M, we have that

ℙ​(M​(D)∈𝒮)≤eε​ℙ​(M​(D′)∈𝒮)+δ,ℙ𝑀𝐷𝒮superscript𝑒𝜀ℙ𝑀superscript𝐷′𝒮𝛿\mathbb{P}\left(M(D)\in\mathcal{S}\right)\leq e^{\varepsilon}\mathbb{P}\left(M(D^{\prime})\in\mathcal{S}\right)+\delta,

where D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} are neighboring pairs if they can be obtained from each other by adding or removing all the records that belong to a particular user.

The above DP notion is referred to as user level DP and is stronger than the commonly-used item level DP, where, if a user contributes multiple records, only the addition or removal of one record is protected.

We also make use of Renyi differential privacy (RDP) which allows for tight privacy accounting.

Definition 3.2 (Renyi Differential Privacy).

A randomized mechanism M𝑀M satisfies (α,ε)𝛼𝜀(\alpha,\varepsilon)-RDP if for any two neighboring datasets D,D′𝐷superscript𝐷′D,D^{\prime}, we have that Dα​(PM​(D),PM​(D′))≤εsubscript𝐷𝛼subscript𝑃𝑀𝐷subscript𝑃𝑀superscript𝐷′𝜀D_{\alpha}\left(P_{M(D)},P_{M(D^{\prime})}\right)\leq\varepsilon where Dα​(P,Q)subscript𝐷𝛼𝑃𝑄D_{\alpha}\left(P,Q\right) is the Renyi divergence between P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q and is given by

Dα​(P,Q)≜1α​log⁡(𝔼Q​[(P​(X)Q​(X))α]).≜subscript𝐷𝛼𝑃𝑄1𝛼subscript𝔼𝑄delimited-[]superscript𝑃𝑋𝑄𝑋𝛼D_{\alpha}\left(P,Q\right)\triangleq\frac{1}{\alpha}\log\left(\mathbb{E}_{Q}\left[\left(\frac{P(X)}{Q(X)}\right)^{\alpha}\right]\right).

Notice that one can convert (α,ε​(α))𝛼𝜀𝛼(\alpha,\varepsilon(\alpha))-RDP to (ε𝖣𝖯​(δ),δ)subscript𝜀𝖣𝖯𝛿𝛿(\varepsilon_{\mathsf{DP}}(\delta),\delta)-DP using the following lemma from Asoodeh et al. (2020); Canonne et al. (2020); Bun & Steinke (2016):

Lemma 3.3.

If M𝑀M satisfies (α,ε)𝛼𝜀\left(\alpha,\varepsilon\right)-RDP, then, for any δ>0𝛿0\delta>0, M𝑀M satisfies (ε𝖣𝖯​(δ),δ)subscript𝜀𝖣𝖯𝛿𝛿\left(\varepsilon_{\mathsf{DP}}(\delta),\delta\right), where

ε𝖣𝖯​(δ)=ε+log⁡(1/α​δ)α−1+log⁡(1−1/α).subscript𝜀𝖣𝖯𝛿𝜀1𝛼𝛿𝛼111𝛼\varepsilon_{\mathsf{DP}}(\delta)=\varepsilon+\frac{\log\left(1/\alpha\delta\right)}{\alpha-1}+\log(1-1/\alpha).

4 Problem Formulation

We start by formally presenting the distributed mean estimation (DME) Suresh et al. (2017) problem under differential privacy. Note that DME is closely related to the federated averaging (FedAvg) algorithm McMahan et al. (2017a), where in each round, the server updates the global model using a noisy estimate of the mean of local model updates. Such a noisy estimate is typically obtained via a DME mechanism, and thus one can easily build a DP-FedAvg scheme from a DP-DME scheme.

Distributed mean estimation under differential privacy

Consider n𝑛n clients each with a data vector xi∈ℝdsubscript𝑥𝑖superscriptℝ𝑑x_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} that satisfies ∥xi∥2≤csubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑥𝑖2𝑐\left\lVert x_{i}\right\rVert_{2}\leq c (e.g., a clipped local model update). After communicating with n𝑛n clients, a server releases a noisy estimates μ^^𝜇\hat{\mu} of the mean μ≜1n​∑ixi≜𝜇1𝑛subscript𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖\mu\triangleq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}x_{i}, such that 1) μ^^𝜇\hat{\mu} satisfies a differential privacy constraint (see Definition 3.1 and Definition 3.2), and 2) 𝔼​[∥μ^−μ∥22]𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥^𝜇𝜇22\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\hat{\mu}-\mu\right\rVert^{2}_{2}\right] is minimized. The goal is to design a communication protocol (which includes local encoders and a central decoder) and an estimator μ^^𝜇\hat{\mu}.

In this paper, we consider two different DP settings. The first is the centralized DP setting: the server has access to all xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}’s, i.e., μ^=μ^​(x1,…,xn)^𝜇^𝜇subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛\hat{\mu}=\hat{\mu}\left(x_{1},...,x_{n}\right). The second is the distributed DP via SecAgg setting: under this setting, each client is subject to a b𝑏b-bit communication constraint, so they must first encode xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} into a b𝑏b-bit message, i.e., Zi=𝒜𝖾𝗇𝖼​(xi)∈𝒵subscript𝑍𝑖subscript𝒜𝖾𝗇𝖼subscript𝑥𝑖𝒵Z_{i}=\mathcal{A}_{\mathsf{enc}}(x_{i})\in\mathcal{Z} with |𝒵|≤2b𝒵superscript2𝑏\left\lvert\mathcal{Z}\right\rvert\leq 2^{b} (See Figure 1 for an illustration). However, instead of directly collecting Z1,…,Znsubscript𝑍1…subscript𝑍𝑛Z_{1},...,Z_{n}, the server can only observe the sum of them, so the estimator must be a function of ∑i=1nZisuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑍𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{n}Z_{i} (i.e., μ^=μ^​(∑i=1nZi)^𝜇^𝜇superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑍𝑖\hat{\mu}=\hat{\mu}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n}Z_{i}\right)). Moreover, we require that the sum ∑iZisubscript𝑖subscript𝑍𝑖\sum_{i}Z_{i} satisfies DP (which is stronger than requiring μ^^𝜇\hat{\mu} to be DP), meaning that individual information will not be disclosed to the server as well. Notice that since SecAgg operates on a finite additive group, we require 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} to have an additive structure. Without loss of generality, we will set 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} to be (ℤM)msuperscriptsubscriptℤ𝑀𝑚\left(\mathbb{Z}_{M}\right)^{m} for some m,M∈ℕ𝑚𝑀ℕm,M\in\mathbb{N}, where ℤMsubscriptℤ𝑀\mathbb{Z}_{M} denotes the group of integers modulo M𝑀M (equipped with modulo M𝑀M addition) and m𝑚m is the dimension of the space we are projecting onto. In other words, we allocate log⁡M𝑀\log M bits for every coordinate of the projected vector. Note that in this case, the total per-client communication cost is b=m​log⁡M𝑏𝑚𝑀b=m\log M.

For a fixed privacy constraint, the fundamental problem we seek to solve is: what is the smallest communication cost under the distributed DP setting needed to achieve the accuracy of the centralized DP setting? Further, we seek to discover schemes that (a) achieve the optimal privacy-accuracy-communication trade-offs and (b) are memory efficient and computationally fast in encoding and decoding.

5 Communication Cost of DME with SecAgg

In this section, we characterize the optimal communication cost under the distributed DP via SecAgg setting, defined as the smallest number of bits (as a function of n,d,ε𝑛𝑑𝜀n,d,\varepsilon) needed to achieve the same accuracy (up to a constant factor) of the centralized setting under the same (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP constraint.

Optimal MSE under central DP

We start by specifying the optimal accuracy under a fully trusted server and no communication constraints. Under a DME setting where ∥xi∥2≤csubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑥𝑖2𝑐\left\lVert x_{i}\right\rVert_{2}\leq c for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} sensitivity of the mean query μ​(x1,…,xn)≜1n​∑i=1nxi≜𝜇subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖\mu(x_{1},...,x_{n})\triangleq\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i} is bounded by

Δ(μ)≜maxxn,x1′∥μ(x1,…,xn)−μ(x1′,…,xn)∥22≤2​c2n.\Delta\left(\mu\right)\triangleq\max_{x^{n},x_{1}^{\prime}}\left\lVert\mu(x_{1},...,x_{n})-\mu(x_{1}^{\prime},...,x_{n})\right\rVert_{2}^{2}\leq\frac{2c^{2}}{n}.

Therefore, to achieve (ε,δ)\varepsilon,\delta) central DP, the server can add coordinate-wise independent Gaussian noise to μ𝜇\mu. This gives an ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} error that scales as Oδ​(c2​dn2​ε2)subscript𝑂𝛿superscript𝑐2𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2O_{\delta}\left(\frac{c^{2}d}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right), which is known to be tight in the high privacy regime Kamath & Ullman (2020). Moreover, the resulting estimator is unbiased333Notice that in this work, we are mostly interest in unbiased estimators (see Remark 5.5 for a discussion)..

Communication costs of DDG

Next, we examine the communication costs of previous distributed DP schemes such as the DDG mechanism. As mentioned in Section 3.2 and Theorem E.1, in order to achieve the Oδ​(c2​dn2​ε2)subscript𝑂𝛿superscript𝑐2𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2O_{\delta}\left(\frac{c^{2}d}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right) error, the communication cost of DDG must to be at least Θ​(d​log⁡(d/ε2))Θ𝑑𝑑superscript𝜀2\Theta\left(d\log\left(d/\varepsilon^{2}\right)\right) bits. Note that the communication cost scales up with 1/ε1𝜀1/\varepsilon because in the high-privacy regimes, the noise variance needs to be increased accordingly to provide stronger DP. Thus SecAgg’s group size needs to be enlarged to capture the larger signal range and avoid catastrophic modular clipping errors. A similar phenomenon occurs for other additive noise-based mechanisms, e.g, the Skellam and binomial Agarwal et al. (2018, 2021) mechanisms.

However, we show that the Θ​(d​log⁡(d/ε2))Θ𝑑𝑑superscript𝜀2\Theta\left(d\log\left(d/\varepsilon^{2}\right)\right) cost is strictly sub-optimal. In particular, the linear dependency on d𝑑d can be further improved when n2​ε2≪dmuch-less-thansuperscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2𝑑n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}\ll d. To demonstrate this, we start by the following example to show that under a (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta) central DP constraint, one can reduce the dimensionality to m=O​(n2​ε2)𝑚𝑂superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2m=O(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}) without harming the MSE.

Dimensionality reduction under central DP

Consider the following simple project-and-perturb mechanism:

  1. 1.

    The server generates a random projection matrix S∈ℝm×d𝑆superscriptℝ𝑚𝑑S\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times d} according to the sparse random projection defined in Section 3.3 and broadcasts it to n𝑛n clients.

  2. 2.

    Each client sends yi≜𝖼𝗅𝗂𝗉ℓ2,1.1​c​(S​xi)≜subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝖼𝗅𝗂𝗉subscriptℓ21.1𝑐𝑆subscript𝑥𝑖y_{i}\triangleq\mathsf{clip}_{\ell_{2},1.1c}\left(Sx_{i}\right).

  3. 3.

    The server computes μ^≜S⊺​(1n​∑iyi+N​(0,σ2​𝕀m))≜^𝜇superscript𝑆⊺1𝑛subscript𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑁0superscript𝜎2subscript𝕀𝑚\hat{\mu}\triangleq S^{\intercal}\left(\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}y_{i}+N\left(0,\sigma^{2}\mathbb{I}_{m}\right)\right), where σ2=Θ​(c2n2​ε2)superscript𝜎2Θsuperscript𝑐2superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2\sigma^{2}=\Theta\left(\frac{c^{2}}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right).

We claim that the above project-and-perturb approach satisfies (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta) DP and achieves the optimal MSE order. In other words, we can reduce the dimensionality for free.

To see why this is true, observe that we can decompose the overall ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} error ∥μ^−μ∥22subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥^𝜇𝜇22\left\lVert\hat{\mu}-\mu\right\rVert^{2}_{2} into three parts: (1) the clipping error (i.e., ∥yi−S​xi∥22subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑦𝑖𝑆subscript𝑥𝑖22\left\lVert y_{i}-Sx_{i}\right\rVert^{2}_{2}), (2) the compression error (i.e. ∥μ−S⊺​S​(∑ixi/n)∥22subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜇superscript𝑆⊺𝑆subscript𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖𝑛22\left\lVert\mu-S^{\intercal}S\left(\sum_{i}x_{i}/n\right)\right\rVert^{2}_{2}), and (3) the privatization error ∥S⊺​N​(0,σ2​𝕀m)∥22subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑆⊺𝑁0superscript𝜎2subscript𝕀𝑚22\left\lVert S^{\intercal}N(0,\sigma^{2}\mathbb{I}_{m})\right\rVert^{2}_{2}. Then, we argue that all of them have orders less than or equal to O​(c2​dn2​ε2)𝑂superscript𝑐2𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2O\left(\frac{c^{2}d}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right), as long as we select m=Θ​(n2​ε2)𝑚Θsuperscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2m=\Theta(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}) and t=Θ​(log⁡d+log⁡(n2​ε2))𝑡Θ𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2t=\Theta\left(\log d+\log(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2})\right).

First, the clipping error is small since the random projection S𝑆S satisfies the Johnson-Lindenstrauss (JL) property (see Lemma 3.5 in the appendix), which implies that ∥S​xi∥2≈∥xi∥2≤csubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑆subscript𝑥𝑖2subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑥𝑖2𝑐\left\lVert Sx_{i}\right\rVert_{2}\approx\left\lVert x_{i}\right\rVert_{2}\leq c and that the clipping happens with exponentially small probability. Second, Lemma 3.4 (in the appendix) suggests that compression error scales as O​(c2​dm)𝑂superscript𝑐2𝑑𝑚O\left(\frac{c^{2}d}{m}\right). Thus by picking m=Θ​(n2​ε2)𝑚Θsuperscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2m=\Theta\left(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}\right), we ensure the compression error to be at most O​(c2​dn2​ε2)𝑂superscript𝑐2𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2O\left(\frac{c^{2}d}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right). Finally, since the Gaussian noise N𝑁N added at Step 3 is independent of S𝑆S, the privatization error can also be bounded by O​(c2​dn2​ε2)𝑂superscript𝑐2𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2O\left(\frac{c^{2}d}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right).

We summarize this in the following lemma, where the formal proof is deferred to Section I.2 in the appendix.

Lemma 5.1.

Assume ∥xi∥2≤csubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑥𝑖2𝑐\left\lVert x_{i}\right\rVert_{2}\leq c for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]. Then the output of the above mechanism μ^^𝜇\hat{\mu} satisfies (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿\left(\varepsilon,\delta\right)-DP. Moreover, if S𝑆S (defined in (2)) is generated with m=Θ​(n2​ε2)𝑚Θsuperscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2m=\Theta(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}) and t=Θ​(log⁡d+log⁡(n2​ε2))𝑡Θ𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2t=\Theta\left(\log d+\log(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2})\right), it holds that 𝔼​[∥μ^−μ∥22]=O​(c2​dn2​ε2)𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥^𝜇𝜇22𝑂superscript𝑐2𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\hat{\mu}-\mu\right\rVert^{2}_{2}\right]=O\left(\frac{c^{2}d}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right).

Dimensionality reduction with SecAgg

The above example shows that with a random projection, we can reduce the dimensionality from d𝑑d to O​(n2​ε2)𝑂superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2O(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}) without increasing the MSE too much. Thus, under the distributed DP via SecAgg setting, we combine random projection with the DDG mechanism to arrive at our main scheme in Algorithm 2.

To control the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} error of Algorithm 2, we adopt the same strategy as in Lemma 5.1 (i.e., decompose the end-to-end error into three parts), with the privatization error being replaced by the error due to DDG. However, this will cause an additional challenge, as the error due to DDG is no longer independent of S𝑆S (as opposed to the Gaussian noise in the previous case). To overcome this difficulty, we leverage the fact that for any projection matrix S𝑆S, the (expected) ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} error is bounded by O​(c2​mn2​ε2)𝑂superscript𝑐2𝑚superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2O\left(\frac{c^{2}m}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right) and develop an upper bound on the final MSE accordingly (see Section F for a formal proof).

We summarize the performance guarantees of Algorithm 2 in the following theorem.

Theorem 5.2.

Let S𝑆S in Algorithm 2 be generated according to (2) with m=Θ​(n2​ε2)𝑚Θsuperscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2m=\Theta(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}) and t=Θ​(log⁡d+log⁡(n2​ε2))𝑡Θ𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2t=\Theta\left(\log d+\log(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2})\right). Assume ∥xi∥≤cdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑥𝑖𝑐\left\lVert x_{i}\right\rVert\leq c for all i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]. Then as long as n2​ε2≤dsuperscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2𝑑n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}\leq d, the following holds:

  • •

    Algorithm 2 satisfies (α,ε22​α)𝛼superscript𝜀22𝛼\left(\alpha,\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{2}\alpha\right)-RDP,

  • •

    the MSE is bounded by 𝔼​[∥μ^−μ∥22]=O​(c2​dn2​ε2),𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥^𝜇𝜇22𝑂superscript𝑐2𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\hat{\mu}-\mu\right\rVert^{2}_{2}\right]=O\left(\frac{c^{2}d}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right),

  • •

    the per-client communication is

    O​(m​log⁡(n+n3​ε2m+mε))=O​(n2​ε2​log⁡n).𝑂𝑚𝑛superscript𝑛3superscript𝜀2𝑚𝑚𝜀𝑂superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2𝑛O\left(m\log\left(n+\sqrt{\frac{n^{3}\varepsilon^{2}}{m}}+\frac{\sqrt{m}}{\varepsilon}\right)\right)=O\left(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}\log n\right).

Lower bounds for private DME with SecAgg

Next, we complement our achievability result in Theorem 5.2 with a matching communication lower bound. Our lower bound indicates that Algorithm 2 is indeed optimal (in terms of communication efficiency), hence characterizing the fundamental privacy-communication-accuracy trade-offs.

The lower bound leverages the fact that under SecAgg, the individual communication budget each client has is equal to the total number of bits the server can observe, which are all equal to the cardinality of the finite group 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z} that SecAgg acts on. Therefore, even if each client sends a b𝑏b-bit message (so the total information transmitted is n⋅b⋅𝑛𝑏n\cdot b bits), the server still can only observe b𝑏b bits information.

With this in mind, to give a per-client communication lower bound under SecAgg, it suffices to lower bound the total number of bits needed for reconstructing a d𝑑d-dim vector (i.e. the mean vector μ𝜇\mu) within a given error (i.e. Oδ​(c2​d/(n2​ε2))subscript𝑂𝛿superscript𝑐2𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2O_{\delta}\left(c^{2}d/(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2})\right)). Towards this end, we first derive a general lower bound that characterizes the communication-accuracy trade-offs for compressing a single d𝑑d-dim vector in a centralized setting.

Theorem 5.3 (compression lower bounds).

Let v∈ℝd𝑣superscriptℝ𝑑v\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and ∥v∥2≤csubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑣2𝑐\left\lVert v\right\rVert_{2}\leq c. Then for any (possibly randomized) compression operator 𝒞:𝐁d​(c)→[2b]:𝒞→subscript𝐁𝑑𝑐delimited-[]superscript2𝑏\mathcal{C}:\mathbf{B}_{d}(c)\rightarrow[2^{b}] that compresses v𝑣v into b𝑏b bits and any (possibly randomized) estimator v^:[2b]→𝐁d​(c):^𝑣→delimited-[]superscript2𝑏subscript𝐁𝑑𝑐\hat{v}:[2^{b}]\rightarrow\mathbf{B}_{d}(c), it holds that

min(𝒞,v^)⁡maxv∈𝐁d​(c)⁡𝔼​[∥v^​(𝒞​(v))−v∥22]≥c2​2−2​b/d.subscript𝒞^𝑣subscript𝑣subscript𝐁𝑑𝑐𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥^𝑣𝒞𝑣𝑣22superscript𝑐2superscript22𝑏𝑑\min_{\left(\mathcal{C},\hat{v}\right)}\max_{v\in\mathbf{B}_{d}(c)}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\hat{v}\left(\mathcal{C}(v)\right)-v\right\rVert^{2}_{2}\right]\geq c^{2}2^{-2b/d}. (5)

Moreover, for any unbiased compression scheme (i.e., (𝒞,v^)𝒞^𝑣\left(\mathcal{C},\hat{v}\right) satisfying 𝔼​[v^​(𝒞​(v))]=v𝔼delimited-[]^𝑣𝒞𝑣𝑣\mathbb{E}\left[\hat{v}\left(\mathcal{C}(v)\right)\right]=v for all v∈𝐁d​(c)𝑣subscript𝐁𝑑𝑐v\in\mathbf{B}_{d}(c)) with b<d𝑏𝑑b<d, it holds that

min(𝒞,v^)⁡maxv∈𝐁d​(c)⁡𝔼​[∥v^​(𝒞​(v))−v∥22]≥C0​c2​d/b,subscript𝒞^𝑣subscript𝑣subscript𝐁𝑑𝑐𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥^𝑣𝒞𝑣𝑣22subscript𝐶0superscript𝑐2𝑑𝑏\min_{\left(\mathcal{C},\hat{v}\right)}\max_{v\in\mathbf{B}_{d}(c)}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\hat{v}\left(\mathcal{C}(v)\right)-v\right\rVert^{2}_{2}\right]\geq C_{0}c^{2}d/b, (6)

where C0>0subscript𝐶00C_{0}>0 is a universal constant.

Theorem 5.3, together with the fact that the per-client bit budget is also the total amount of information the server can observe, we arrive at the following lower bound.

Corollary 5.4.

Consider the private DME task with SecAgg as described in Figure 1. For any encoding function 𝒜𝖾𝗇𝖼​(⋅)subscript𝒜𝖾𝗇𝖼⋅\mathcal{A}_{\mathsf{enc}}(\cdot) with output space 𝒵𝒵\mathcal{Z}, if the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} estimation error 𝔼​[∥μ^−μ∥22]≤ξ𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥^𝜇𝜇22𝜉\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\hat{\mu}-\mu\right\rVert^{2}_{2}\right]\leq\xi for all possible x1,…,xn∈𝐁d​(c)subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝐁𝑑𝑐x_{1},...,x_{n}\in\mathbf{B}_{d}(c), then it must hold that log⁡|𝒵|=Ω​(d​log⁡(c2/ξ)).𝒵Ω𝑑superscript𝑐2𝜉\log\left\lvert\mathcal{Z}\right\rvert=\Omega\left(d\log\left(c^{2}/\xi\right)\right). In addition, if μ^^𝜇\hat{\mu} is unbiased and ξ≤c2𝜉superscript𝑐2\xi\leq c^{2}, then log⁡|𝒵|=Ω​(d​c2/ξ).𝒵Ω𝑑superscript𝑐2𝜉\log\left\lvert\mathcal{Z}\right\rvert=\Omega\left(dc^{2}/\xi\right).

Finally, by plugging ξ=O​(c2​dn2​ε2)𝜉𝑂superscript𝑐2𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2\xi=O\left(\frac{c^{2}d}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right) (which is the optimal ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} error for the mean estimation task under centralized DP model), we conclude that

  • •

    Ω​(max⁡(d​log⁡(n2​ε2/d),1))Ω𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2𝑑1\Omega\left(\max\left(d\log\left({n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}/{d}\right),1\right)\right) bits of communication are necessary for general (possibly biased) schemes

  • •

    Ω​(min⁡(n2​ε2,d))Ωsuperscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2𝑑\Omega\left(\min\left(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2},d\right)\right) bits of communication are necessary for unbiased schemes.

We remark that the above lower bounds are both tight but in different regimes. Specifically, the first lower bound, which measures the accuracy in MSE, is tight for small d𝑑d but is meaningless in high-dimensional or high-privacy regimes where d≫n2​ε2much-greater-than𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2d\gg n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}. This also implies that Ω~​(d)~Ω𝑑\tilde{\Omega}(d) bits are necessary for d≪n2​ε2much-less-than𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2d\ll n^{2}\varepsilon^{2} and that there is no room for improvement on DDG in this regime. On the other hand, the second bound is useful when d=Ω​(n2​ε2)𝑑Ωsuperscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2d=\Omega\left(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}\right) (with an additional unbiasedness assumption). This is a more practical regime for FL with SecAgg, and our scheme outperforms DDG in this scenario.

Remark 5.5.

Notice that in this work, we are mostly interested in unbiased estimators due to the following two reasons: 1) it largely facilities the convergence analysis of the SGD based methods, as these types of stochastic first-order methods usually assume access to an unbiased gradient estimator in each round. 2) In the high-dimensional or high-privacy regimes where d≫n2​ε2much-greater-than𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2d\gg n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}, the MSE is not the right performance measure since an estimator can have a large bias while still achieving a relative small MSE. For instance, in the regime where n2​ε2≤dsuperscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2𝑑n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}\leq d, the Gaussian mechanism has MSE Θ​(c2​dn2​ε2)Θsuperscript𝑐2𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2\Theta\left(\frac{c^{2}d}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right); on the other hand, the trivial estimator μ^=0^𝜇0\hat{\mu}=0 achieves a smaller MSE, equal to c2≤O​(c2​dn2​ε2)superscript𝑐2𝑂superscript𝑐2𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2c^{2}\leq O\left(\frac{c^{2}d}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right), but such estimator gives no meaningful information. In order to rule out these impractical schemes, we hence impose the unbiasedness constraint.

6 Sparse DME with SecAgg and DP

Theorem 5.2 in Section 5.5 specifies the optimal trade-offs of private DME for all possible datasets xnsuperscript𝑥𝑛x^{n}. In other words, it provides a worst-case (over all possible xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}) bound on the utility and shows that Algorithm 2 is worst-case optimal. However, we show in this section that with additional assumptions on the data, it is possible to improve the trade-offs beyond what is given in Theorem 5.2.

One such assumption is sparsity of the data, which is justified by several empirical results that gradients tend to be (or are close to being) sparse. We hence study the sparse DME problem, which is formulated as in Section 4 but with an additional s𝑠s-sparsity assumption on μ𝜇\mu, i.e., ∥μ∥0≤ssubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜇0𝑠\left\lVert\mu\right\rVert_{0}\leq s. We present a sparse DME algorithm adapted from Algorithm 2, showing that by leveraging the sparse structure of data, one can surpass the lower bound in Theorem 5.2. Moreover, the dependency of communication cost and MSE on the model size d𝑑d becomes logarithmic.

DME via compressed sensing

We adopt the same strategy as in Section 5.5, (i.e., use a linear compression scheme to reduce dimensionality). However, instead of applying the linear decoder S⊺​μ^ysuperscript𝑆⊺subscript^𝜇𝑦S^{\intercal}\hat{\mu}_{y}, we perform a more complicated compressed sensing decoding procedure and solve a (regularized) linear inverse problem. Specifically, we modify Algorithm 2 in the following way:

  1. 1.

    For local compression, we replace the sparse random projection matrix S∈ℝm×d𝑆superscriptℝ𝑚𝑑S\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times d} with an s𝑠s-RIP444See Definition H.2 for a weaker definition. matrix (in particular, we use a Gaussian ensemble, i.e., Si,j​∼i.i.d.​N​(0,1)subscript𝑆𝑖𝑗i.i.d.similar-to𝑁01S_{i,j}\overset{\text{i.i.d.}}{\sim}N(0,1)) and set m=O​(s​log⁡d)𝑚𝑂𝑠𝑑m=O\left(s\log d\right).

  2. 2.

    To decode μ^^𝜇\hat{\mu}, the server solves the following ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1} regularized linear inverse problem (7) (i.e., LASSO (Tibshirani, 1996)) where the λnsubscript𝜆𝑛\lambda_{n} is set to be of the order O​(c​log⁡dn​ε)𝑂𝑐𝑑𝑛𝜀O\left(\frac{c\log d}{n\varepsilon}\right).

With the above modifications, we arrive at Algorithm 3:

The next theorem provides the privacy and utility guarantees of Algorithm 3.

Theorem 6.1 (Sparse private DME).

Algorithm 3 satisfies (α,12​ε2​α)𝛼12superscript𝜀2𝛼(\alpha,\frac{1}{2}\varepsilon^{2}\alpha)-RDP. In addition, if ∥μ∥0≤ssubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜇0𝑠\left\lVert\mu\right\rVert_{0}\leq s, it holds that

  • •

    the per-client communication cost is O​(s​log⁡d​log⁡(n2+s​log⁡d/ε2))𝑂𝑠𝑑superscript𝑛2𝑠𝑑superscript𝜀2O\left(s\log d\log\left(n^{2}+{s\log d}/{\varepsilon^{2}}\right)\right);

  • •

    the MSE is bounded by O​(c2​s​log2⁡dn2​ε2)𝑂superscript𝑐2𝑠superscript2𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2O\left(\frac{c^{2}s\log^{2}d}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}\right).

Observe that under sparsity, both the accuracy and the communication cost depend on d𝑑d logarithmically. This implies that by leveraging the sparsity, we can replace d𝑑d with an “effective” dimension of s​log⁡d𝑠𝑑s\log d. However, Algorithm 3 is more complicated than Algorithm 2 as it requires tuning hyper-parameters such as s𝑠s and λnsubscript𝜆𝑛\lambda_{n}.

Remark 6.2.

The communication cost in Theorem 6.1 no longer depends only on n​ε𝑛𝜀n\varepsilon, thus exhibiting a different behavior from the non-sparse case (i.e., that of Theorem 5.2). We remark that this is because we only present the result for the s​log⁡d≪n2​ε2much-less-than𝑠𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2s\log d\ll n^{2}\varepsilon^{2} (which is more reasonable in practice). However, one can extend the similar analysis in Section 5.5 and obtain the results for s​log⁡d≫n2​ε2much-greater-than𝑠𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2s\log d\gg n^{2}\varepsilon^{2} regime.

7 Empirical Analysis

We run experiments on the full Federated EMNIST and Stack Overflow datasets (Caldas et al., 2018), two common benchmarks for FL tasks. F-EMNIST has 626262 classes and N=3400𝑁3400N=3400 clients with a total of 671,585671585671,585 training samples. Inputs are single-channel (28,28)2828(28,28) images. The Stack Overflow (SO) dataset is a large-scale text dataset based on responses to questions asked on the site Stack Overflow. The are over 108superscript10810^{8} data samples unevenly distributed across N=342477𝑁342477N=342477 clients. We focus on the next word prediction (NWP) task: given a sequence of words, predict the next words in the sequence. On both datasets, we select n∈[100,1000]𝑛1001000n\in[100,1000] and R=1500𝑅1500R=1500. On F-EMNIST, we experiment with a ≈106absentsuperscript106\approx 10^{6} parameter (4 layer) Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) used by Kairouz et al. (2021a). On SONWP, we experiment with a ≈4⋅106absent⋅4superscript106\approx 4\cdot 10^{6} parameter (4 layer) long-short term memory (LSTM) model—the same as prior work Andrew et al. (2021); Kairouz et al. (2021a). In both cases, clients train for 111 local epoch using SGD. Only the server uses momentum. For distributed DP, we use the geometric adaptive clipping of Andrew et al. (2021). We use the same procedure as Kairouz et al. (2021a). We randomly rotate vectors using the Discrete Fourier Transform. We use their hyperparameter values for conditional randomized rounding and modular clipping. We communicate 161616 bits per parameter for F-EMNIST and 181818 for SONWP unless otherwise indicated. We repeat all experiments with 555 different seeds (or more, where stated). We provide full detail on the models, datasets, and training setups in Appendix B, as well as the chosen values of the noise multiplier and sparse random projections (via sketching) parameters in Appendix C. We provide details of our algorithms for sparse random projections (via sketching) in Appendix D.

Analyzing the privacy-utility-communication tradeoff

We now study the best compression rates that we can attain without significantly impacting the current performance. For this, we train models that achieve state-of-the-art performance on the FL tasks we consider, and allow a slack of Δ=4%Δpercent4\Delta=4\% relative to these models when trained without compression (r=1𝑟1r=1x). We first consider z=0𝑧0z=0, i.e., no DP, and see that about r=4𝑟4r=4x compression can be attained. However, recall that our theoretical results suggest that as z𝑧z increases and thus ε𝜀\varepsilon decreases, fewer bits of communication are needed. Our experiments echo this finding: at z=0.3𝑧0.3z=0.3, we observe r=5𝑟5r=5x is now attainable and at z≥0.5𝑧0.5z\geq 0.5, r=10𝑟10r=10x is attainable. The highest z𝑧z we display can correspond both to a tighter privacy regime (ε≈10𝜀10\varepsilon\approx 10 or less) but, importantly also to models that are still highly performant indicating that a practitioner could reasonably select both these z𝑧z and r𝑟r to train models comparable to the state-of-the-art. Our experiments on F-EMNIST in Figure 2(b) show similar findings where fixing r≥50𝑟50r\geq 50x can attain z≥0.5𝑧0.5z\geq 0.5 for ‘free’. Finally, these results also corroborate that our bound of O~​(min⁡(n2​ε2,d))~𝑂superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2𝑑\tilde{O}\left(\min(n^{2}\varepsilon^{2},d)\right) is significantly less (≈10absent10\approx 10x) than that of Kairouz et al. (2021a) in practice.

Finding that we can significantly compress our models, another question that can be asked is ‘could a smaller model have been used instead?’ To investigate this, we train a smaller model (denoted ‘small’) which has only ≈2⋅105absent⋅2superscript105\approx 2\cdot 10^{5} parameters, which is comparable in size to the original CNN model updates compressed by r≈5𝑟5r\approx 5x. We observe that this model has significantly lower performance (>5​p​pabsent5𝑝𝑝>5pp) across all privacy budgets when we compare them for a fixed latent dimension of l​e​n​g​t​h×w​i​d​t​h𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ𝑤𝑖𝑑𝑡ℎlength\times width. When we compress our original model beyond r=5𝑟5r=5x (smaller than the ‘small’ model), we find that it still significantly outperforms it. These results indicate that training larger models do in fact attain higher performance even for the same latent update size: further, our results indicate we can enable training these larger models under the same fixed total communication.

Quantization or dimensionality reduction?

Though we achieve significant compression rates from our linear dimensionality reduction technique, we now explore how these results compare with compression via quantization. Theoretically our bound can achieve a minimum compression independent of the ambient gradient size d𝑑d. Because of this, we also expect our methods to outperform those based on quantization because their communication scales with d𝑑d.

Our results in Figure 3 and Table 1 corroborate this hypothesis. We compare our compression against conditional randomized rounding to an integer grid of field size 2bsuperscript2𝑏2^{b}. We vary the quantization (bits) per parameter b𝑏b while allowing the same ΔΔ\Delta as above. Combined with dimensionality reduction, this gives a total communication per ambient parameter as b/r𝑏𝑟b/r. When we use the vanilla distributed DP scheme of Kairouz et al. (2021a), we find that we can only compress to 101010 bits per parameter on SONWP; if we instead favour our linear dimensionality reduction technique, we achieve a much lower 1.21.21.2 bits per parameter (with r=10𝑟10r=10x and b=12𝑏12b=12). For F-EMNIST, we find we can compress down to 0.240.240.24 bits per parameter at z=0.5𝑧0.5z=0.5 by optimizing both b𝑏b and r𝑟r; this is much lower than using only quantization (101010 bits per parameter) and a marginal increase over only dimensionality reduction (0.270.270.27). We observe 0.70.70.7 bits per parameter at z=0.3𝑧0.3z=0.3 and 1.21.21.2 at z=0.1𝑧0.1z=0.1. See Figure 5 for results with z=0.1,0.3𝑧0.10.3z=0.1,0.3 and Figure 6 for the comprehensive results at many r𝑟r and b𝑏b, both in Appendix A.

Because of this, we now explore if raising the b𝑏b (decreasing quantization), past the max b=18𝑏18b=18 bits per parameter that we have considered thus far, will decrease the total communication. Inspecting b=18→22𝑏18→22b=18\to 22 in Figure 3 we do observe a marginal increase in test performance with increasing b𝑏b in some cases, indicating there may be potential to increase r𝑟r. However, we do not find that we can significantly increase r𝑟r in these cases (see Figure 6 of Appendix A).

Impact of cohort size

We conduct experiments under (approximately, because varying n𝑛n impacts ε𝜀\varepsilon) fixed ε𝜀\varepsilon to investigate how the cohort size n𝑛n impacts compression. From Theorem 5.3, we expect to see that as n𝑛n increases, so does does communication. Our empirical results closely match, shown in Figure 8 of Appendix A. Further, we observe from Table 8 of Appendix A that under sufficiently high z𝑧z, we can increase n𝑛n while keeping the total message size fixed (increase r𝑟r by d/(n2n1​log⁡n2log⁡n1)𝑑subscript𝑛2subscript𝑛1subscript𝑛2subscript𝑛1d/(\frac{n_{2}}{n_{1}}\frac{\log{n_{2}}}{\log{n_{1}}}), where n2>n1subscript𝑛2subscript𝑛1n_{2}>n_{1}) to improve the model performance. In other words, in large n𝑛n scenarios where SecAgg can fail (due to large communication), our protocol may enable a practitioner to still increase n𝑛n to obtain better performance.

We attempted to improve compression rates by compressing layers separately (per-layer) or thresholding the noisy aggregate random projections. We found neither achieved significant improvements. The former aligns with results from McMahan et al. (2017b) in central DP. See Appendix A.2 for this.

8 Conclusion

In this paper, we study the optimal privacy-communication-accuracy trade-offs under distributed DP via SecAgg. We show that existing schemes are order optimal when d≪n2​ε2much-less-than𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2d\ll n^{2}\varepsilon^{2} and strictly sub-optimal otherwise. To address this issue, we provide an optimal scheme that leverages sparse random projections. We also show how our scheme can be minimally modified when the client updates are sparse to further improve the trade-offs. Our extensive experiments on FL benchmark datasets demonstrate significant communication gains (∼similar-to\sim10x) relative to existing schemes. Many important questions remain open, including obtaining a fundamental characterization of the privacy-accuracy-communication trade-offs under other models of distributed DP (e.g. via a trusted third-party or in a secure enclave as in Bittau et al. (2017); Ghazi et al. (2020b, 2021, c, a); Ishai et al. (2006); Balle et al. (2019, 2020); Balcer & Cheu (2020); Balcer et al. (2021); Girgis et al. (2021b, a); Erlingsson et al. (2019)).

Appendix A Additional Figures

A.1 Impact of cohort size

Finally, we explore how varying the number of clients per round (or, cohort size) n𝑛n impacts the privacy-utility-communication tradeoff. This value plays several key roles in this tradeoff. First, increasing n𝑛n increases the sampling probability of the cohort, which increases the total privacy expenditure. However, it also tends to improve model performance—this may mean that a higher noise multiplier z𝑧z can be chosen so as to instead decrease the total privacy cost (this is typically the case when N is large enough, e.g., SO). In terms of communication, Theorem 5.2 suggests that increasing n𝑛n will also increase the per-client comunication. Because of the aforementioned complex tradeoffs, we (approximately) fix the privacy budget ε𝜀\varepsilon and only perturb n𝑛n minimally around a nominal value of 100100100. In Figure 8, we see that dependence of communication on n𝑛n is observed empirically as well.

In addition to this impact on r𝑟r, setting n𝑛n can also have a significant impact on the run time of SecAgg, of O​(n​log⁡(n)​d)𝑂𝑛𝑛𝑑O(n\log(n)d). For large values of n𝑛n, this can entirely prevent the protocol from completing. Because a practitioner desires the most performant model, a common goal is the increase n𝑛n so as to obtain a tight ε𝜀\varepsilon (due to a now higher z𝑧z) with the least cost in performance. But, because large n𝑛n can crash SecAgg, this places a constraint on the maximum n𝑛n that can be chosen. Since our methods compress the updates (d𝑑d above), it is possible to still increase n𝑛n so long as we increase r𝑟r accordingly (by n2n1​log⁡n2log⁡n1subscript𝑛2subscript𝑛1subscript𝑛2subscript𝑛1\frac{n_{2}}{n_{1}}\frac{\log{n_{2}}}{\log{n_{1}}} where n2>n1subscript𝑛2subscript𝑛1n_{2}>n_{1}), which maintains fixed runtime. If the resulting model at higher n𝑛n achieves higher performance, then we observe a net benefit from this tradeoff. For a practical privacy parameter or z=0.6𝑧0.6z=0.6, our results in Table 8 suggest that this may be possible. Specifically, increasing n𝑛n from 100→1000→1001000100\to 1000 and settings r=50​x>15​x𝑟50𝑥15𝑥r=50x>15x accordingly, we observe that the final model with n=1000𝑛1000n=1000 clients achieves a nearly 555pp gain. We observe that z<0.3𝑧0.3z<0.3 cannot meet these requirements.

A.2 Attempting to improve compression via per-layer sketching and thresholding

We attempted two additional methods to improve our compression rates. First, we noticed that the LSTM models we trained had consistently different ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norms across layers in training. Because these norms are different, we hypothesizes that sketching and perturbing them separately may improve the model utility. We attempt this protocol in Figures 9 and 10, where Figure 9 uses z=0.05𝑧0.05z=0.05 and Figure10 uses z=0𝑧0z=0. We find that, in general, there are no significant performance gains. We further attempt to threshold low values in the sketch. Because this leads to a biased estimate of the gradient, we keep track of the zero-d values in an error term. We tried several threshold values and we found that this as well led to no significant performance gains.

Appendix B Datasets and Training Setup

We run experiments on the full Federated EMNIST and Stack Overflow datasets (Caldas et al., 2018), two common benchmarks for FL tasks. F-EMNIST has 626262 classes and N=3400𝑁3400N=3400 clients, with each user holding both a train and test set of examples. In total, there are 671,585671585671,585 training examples and 77,4837748377,483 test examples. Inputs are single-channel (28,28)2828(28,28) images. We sample n∈[100,1000]𝑛1001000n\in[100,1000] clients per round for a total R=1500𝑅1500R=1500 rounds. The Stack Overflow (SO) dataset is a large-scale text dataset based on responses to questions asked on the site Stack Overflow. The are over 108superscript10810^{8} data samples unevenly distributed across N=342477𝑁342477N=342477 clients. We focus on the next word prediction (NWP) task: given a sequence of words, predict the next words in the sequence. We sample use n∈[100,1000]𝑛1001000n\in[100,1000] and R=1500𝑅1500R=1500. On F-EMNIST, we experiment with a ≈1absent1\approx 1 million parameter (4 layer) Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) used by (Kairouz et al., 2021a). On SONWP, we experiment with a ≈4absent4\approx 4 million parameter (4 layer) long-short term memory (LSTM) model, which is the same as prior work Andrew et al. (2021); Kairouz et al. (2021a).

On F-EMNIST, we use a server learning rate of 1.11. normalized by n𝑛n (the number of clients) and momentum of 0.90.90.9 (Polyak, 1964); the client uses a learning rate of 0.010.010.01 without momentum. On Stack Overflow, we use a server learning rate of 1.781.781.78 normalized by n𝑛n and momentum of 0.90.90.9; the client uses a learning rate of 0.30.30.3.

For distributed DP, we use the geometric adaptive clipping of Andrew et al. (2021) with an initial ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} clipping norm of 0.10.10.1 and a target quantile of 0.50.50.5. We use the same procedure as Kairouz et al. (2021a) and flatten using the Discrete Fourier Transform, pick β=exp⁡(−0.5)𝛽0.5\beta=\exp{(-0.5)} as the conditional randomized rounding bias, and use a modular clipping target probability of 6.33​e−56.33e56.33\mathrm{e}{-5} or ≈4absent4\approx 4 standard deviations at the server (assuming normally distributed updates). We communicate 161616 bits per parameter for F-EMNIST and 181818 bits for SONWP unless otherwise indicated.

On F-EMNIST, our ‘large’ model corresponds to the CNN whereas our ‘small’ model corresponds to an ≈200,000absent200000\approx 200,000 parameter model with 333 dense layers (see Figure 12).

Appendix C Empirical Details of DP and Linear Compression

Noise multiplier to ε𝜀\mathbf{\varepsilon}-DP

We specify the privacy budgets in terms of the noise multiplier z𝑧z, which together with the clients per round n𝑛n, total clients N𝑁N, number of rounds R𝑅R, and the clipping threshold completely specify the trained model ε𝜀\varepsilon-DP. Because the final ε𝜀\mathbf{\varepsilon}-DP values depend on the sampling method: e.g., Poisson vs. fixed batch sampling, which depends on the production implementation of the FL system, we report the noise multipliers instead. Using Canonne et al. (2020); Mironov (2017), our highest noise multipliers roughly correspond to ε={5,10}𝜀510\varepsilon=\{5,10\} using δ=1/N𝛿1𝑁\delta=1/N and privacy amplification via fixed batch sampling.

Linear compression

We display results in terms of the noise multiplier which fully specifies the ε𝜀\varepsilon-DP given our other parameters (n𝑛n, N𝑁N, and R𝑅R). We discuss this choice in Appendix C. We use a sparse random projection (i.e. a count sketch together with a mean estimator) which compresses gradients to a sketch matrix of size (l​e​n​g​t​h𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎlength,w​i​d​t​h𝑤𝑖𝑑𝑡ℎwidth). We test l​e​n​g​t​h∈{10,15,20,25}𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎ10152025length\in\{10,15,20,25\} and find that 151515 leads to optimal final test performance. We use this value for all our experiments and calculate the w​i​d​t​h=d/(r⋅l​e​n​g​t​h)𝑤𝑖𝑑𝑡ℎ𝑑⋅𝑟𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎwidth=d/(r\cdot length) where g​r​a​d​i​e​n​t∈ℛd𝑔𝑟𝑎𝑑𝑖𝑒𝑛𝑡superscriptℛ𝑑gradient\in\mathcal{R}^{d} and r𝑟r is the compression rate. We normalize each sketch row by the l​e​n​g​t​h𝑙𝑒𝑛𝑔𝑡ℎlength to lower the clipping norm, finding some improvements in our results. Thus, decoding requires only summing the gradient estimate from each row. We provide the full algorithms in below in Appendix D.

Bounding the compression error

Next, by Lemma 3.4, the compression error can be bounded by

𝔼​[∥(S⊺​1n​∑iyi−μ)∥22]≤2​c2​dm.𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑆⊺1𝑛subscript𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝜇222superscript𝑐2𝑑𝑚\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\left(S^{\intercal}\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}y_{i}-\mu\right)\right\rVert^{2}_{2}\right]\leq\frac{2c^{2}d}{m}.

Putting things together, we obtain

𝔼​[∥μ^−μ∥22]𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥^𝜇𝜇22\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\hat{\mu}-\mu\right\rVert^{2}_{2}\right] ≤C1​c2​dn2​ε2+2​c2​dm+c2​(d+1)​β.absentsubscript𝐶1superscript𝑐2𝑑superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀22superscript𝑐2𝑑𝑚superscript𝑐2𝑑1𝛽\displaystyle\leq C_{1}\frac{c^{2}d}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}+\frac{2c^{2}d}{m}+c^{2}(d+1)\beta.

Therefore if we pick β=1n2​ε2𝛽1superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2\beta=\frac{1}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}} (so m𝑚m has to be log⁡(n3​ε2)superscript𝑛3superscript𝜀2\log\left(n^{3}\varepsilon^{2}\right)), and m=n2​ε2𝑚superscript𝑛2superscript𝜀2m=n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}, we have

Appendix H Proof of Theorem 6.1

The 12​ε212superscript𝜀2\frac{1}{2}\varepsilon^{2}-concentrated DP is guaranteed by the DDG mechanism. Before we continue to analyze the error, we first introduce some necessary definitions.

Definition H.1 (Restricted eigenvalue (RE) condition (Raskutti et al., 2010)).

A matrix S∈ℝm×d𝑆superscriptℝ𝑚𝑑S\in\mathbb{R}^{m\times d} satisfies the restricted eigenvalue (RE) condition over 𝒮⊆[d]𝒮delimited-[]𝑑\mathcal{S}\subseteq[d] with parameter (κ,α)𝜅𝛼(\kappa,\alpha) if

1m​∥S​Δ∥22≥κ​∥Δ∥22,∀Δ∈𝖢α​(𝒮),formulae-sequence1𝑚subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑆Δ22𝜅subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥Δ22for-allΔsubscript𝖢𝛼𝒮\frac{1}{m}\left\lVert S\Delta\right\rVert^{2}_{2}\geq\kappa\left\lVert\Delta\right\rVert^{2}_{2},\,\forall\Delta\in\mathsf{C}_{\alpha}(\mathcal{S}),

where 𝖢α​(𝒮)≜{Δ∈ℝd|∥Δ𝒮c∥1≤α​∥Δ𝒮∥1}≜subscript𝖢𝛼𝒮conditional-setΔsuperscriptℝ𝑑subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscriptΔsuperscript𝒮𝑐1𝛼subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscriptΔ𝒮1\mathsf{C}_{\alpha}\left(\mathcal{S}\right)\triangleq\left\{\Delta\in\mathbb{R}^{d}|\left\lVert\Delta_{\mathcal{S}^{c}}\right\rVert_{1}\leq\alpha\left\lVert\Delta_{\mathcal{S}}\right\rVert_{1}\right\}. In addition, the communication cost is

H.1 Parameter selection

Now we pick parameters so that Algorithm 1 satisfies 12​ε212superscript𝜀2\frac{1}{2}\varepsilon^{2}-concentrated DP and attains the MSE as in the centralized model. To begin with, we first determine σ𝜎\sigma so that Algorithm 1 satisfies differential privacy.

Privacy analysis

To analyze the privacy guarantees, we treat the inner discrete Gaussian mechanism as a black box with the following parameters: effective dimension d′=msuperscript𝑑′𝑚d^{\prime}=m, ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} bound (or the clipping threshold) c′=c​σ𝗆𝖺𝗑​(S)superscript𝑐′𝑐subscript𝜎𝗆𝖺𝗑𝑆c^{\prime}=c\sigma_{\mathsf{max}}(S), granularity γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0, noise scale σ>0𝜎0\sigma>0, and bias β∈[0,1)𝛽01\beta\in[0,1). Define

Δ22subscriptsuperscriptΔ22\displaystyle\Delta^{2}_{2} ≜min⁡{c′⁣2+γ2​d′4+2​log⁡(1/β)​γ​(c′+γ2​d′),(c′+γ​d′)2}≜absentsuperscript𝑐′2superscript𝛾2superscript𝑑′421𝛽𝛾superscript𝑐′𝛾2superscript𝑑′superscriptsuperscript𝑐′𝛾superscript𝑑′2\displaystyle\triangleq\min\left\{c^{\prime 2}+\frac{\gamma^{2}d^{\prime}}{4}+\sqrt{2\log\left(1/\beta\right)}\gamma\left(c^{\prime}+\frac{\gamma}{2}\sqrt{d^{\prime}}\right),\left(c^{\prime}+\gamma\sqrt{d^{\prime}}\right)^{2}\right\}
τ𝜏\displaystyle\tau ≜10​∑k=1n−1exp⁡(−2​π2​σ2γ2​kk+1)≜absent10superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛12superscript𝜋2superscript𝜎2superscript𝛾2𝑘𝑘1\displaystyle\triangleq 10\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}\exp\left(-2\pi^{2}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\gamma^{2}}\frac{k}{k+1}\right)
ε𝜀\displaystyle\varepsilon ≜min⁡{Δ22n​σ2+12​τ​d′,Δ2n​σ+τ​d′}.≜absentsubscriptsuperscriptΔ22𝑛superscript𝜎212𝜏superscript𝑑′subscriptΔ2𝑛𝜎𝜏superscript𝑑′\displaystyle\triangleq\min\left\{\sqrt{\frac{\Delta^{2}_{2}}{n\sigma^{2}}+\frac{1}{2}\tau d^{\prime}},\frac{\Delta_{2}}{\sqrt{n\sigma}}+\tau\sqrt{d^{\prime}}\right\}.

Then Theorem 1 in Kairouz et al. (2021a) ensures that Algorithm 1 is 12​ε212superscript𝜀2\frac{1}{2}\varepsilon^{2}-concentrated DP. With this theorem in hands, we first determine σ𝜎\sigma. Observe that

ε2≤Δ22n​σ2+12​τ​d′≤2​c′⁣2n​σ2+2​d′n​(σ/γ)2+5​n​d′​exp−π2​(σ/γ)2.superscript𝜀2subscriptsuperscriptΔ22𝑛superscript𝜎212𝜏superscript𝑑′2superscript𝑐′2𝑛superscript𝜎22superscript𝑑′𝑛superscript𝜎𝛾25𝑛superscript𝑑′superscriptsuperscript𝜋2superscript𝜎𝛾2\varepsilon^{2}\leq\frac{\Delta^{2}_{2}}{n\sigma^{2}}+\frac{1}{2}\tau d^{\prime}\leq\frac{2c^{\prime 2}}{n\sigma^{2}}+\frac{2d^{\prime}}{n(\sigma/\gamma)^{2}}+5nd^{\prime}\exp^{-\pi^{2}(\sigma/\gamma)^{2}}.

Thus it suffices to set σ=max⁡{2​c′ε​n,γ​8​d′ε​n,γπ2​log⁡(20​n​d′ε2)}=Θ~​(c′ε​n+d′n​γε)𝜎2superscript𝑐′𝜀𝑛𝛾8superscript𝑑′𝜀𝑛𝛾superscript𝜋220𝑛superscript𝑑′superscript𝜀2~Θsuperscript𝑐′𝜀𝑛superscript𝑑′𝑛𝛾𝜀\sigma=\max\left\{\frac{2c^{\prime}}{\varepsilon\sqrt{n}},\frac{\gamma\sqrt{8d^{\prime}}}{\varepsilon\sqrt{n}},\frac{\gamma}{\pi^{2}}\log\left(\frac{20nd^{\prime}}{\varepsilon^{2}}\right)\right\}=\tilde{\Theta}\left(\frac{c^{\prime}}{\varepsilon\sqrt{n}}+\sqrt{\frac{d^{\prime}}{n}}\frac{\gamma}{\varepsilon}\right).

Accuracy analysis

We set β=min⁡(γn,1n)𝛽𝛾𝑛1𝑛\beta=\min\left(\sqrt{\frac{\gamma}{n}},\frac{1}{n}\right), and together with the upper bound (13) and

we have

λn=Θ​(1n​(log⁡d+log⁡(1/δ))​(c′⁣2+γ2​d′n​ε2+γ2​log2⁡(n​d′ε2)+γ2)​(maxi=1,…,d∥Si∥22m)).\lambda_{n}=\Theta\left(\sqrt{\frac{1}{n}\left(\log d+\log(1/\delta)\right)\left(\frac{c^{\prime 2}+\gamma^{2}d^{\prime}}{n\varepsilon^{2}}+\gamma^{2}\log^{2}\left(\frac{nd^{\prime}}{\varepsilon^{2}}\right)+\gamma^{2}\right)\left(\frac{\max_{i=1,...,d}\left\lVert S_{i}\right\rVert^{2}_{2}}{m}\right)}\right).

We summarize the above parameter selection in the following theorem.

Algorithm 6 is 12​ε212superscript𝜀2\frac{1}{2}\varepsilon^{2}-concentrated DP, and with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta,

I.2 Proof of Lemma 5.1

Next, we control each term separately. The first term can be controlled using Lemma 3.4, which gives

𝔼​[∥1n​∑iS⊺​S​xi−μ∥22]≤2​dm.𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥1𝑛subscript𝑖superscript𝑆⊺𝑆subscript𝑥𝑖𝜇222𝑑𝑚\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}S^{\intercal}Sx_{i}-\mu\right\rVert^{2}_{2}\right]\leq\frac{2d}{m}.

𝔼[∥S⊺⋅N∥22]=𝔼[𝔼[S⊺⋅N|S]]≤σ2d=8​d​(1+α)​log⁡(1.25)n2​ε2.\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\left[\left\lVert S^{\intercal}\cdot N\right\rVert^{2}_{2}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{E}\left[S^{\intercal}\cdot N\middle|S\right]\right]\leq\sigma^{2}d=\frac{8d(1+\alpha)\log\left(1.25\right)}{n^{2}\varepsilon^{2}}.

Notice that we can make α𝛼\alpha and κ𝜅\kappa small, say α=κ=0.1𝛼𝜅0.1\alpha=\kappa=0.1, and the MSE will be closed to the uncompressed one.

I.3 Proof of Lemma H.5

We first set some notation. Let μy=S​μ=1n​∑iyisubscript𝜇𝑦𝑆𝜇1𝑛subscript𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖\mu_{y}=S\mu=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}y_{i}, z=U​μy𝑧𝑈subscript𝜇𝑦z=U\mu_{y} (where U𝑈U is the random rotation matrix), z~=1n​∑i(RγG​(zi)+𝒩ℤ​(0,σ2/γ2))~𝑧1𝑛subscript𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝐺𝛾subscript𝑧𝑖subscript𝒩ℤ0superscript𝜎2superscript𝛾2\tilde{z}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}\left(R^{G}_{\gamma}(z_{i})+\mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{Z}}(0,\sigma^{2}/\gamma^{2})\right), z^=1n​M[−r,r]​(n​z~)^𝑧1𝑛subscript𝑀𝑟𝑟𝑛~𝑧\hat{z}=\frac{1}{n}M_{[-r,r]}(n\tilde{z}) and finally μ^y=U⊺​z^subscript^𝜇𝑦superscript𝑈⊺^𝑧\hat{\mu}_{y}=U^{\intercal}\hat{z}, where RγG​(⋅)subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝐺𝛾⋅R^{G}_{\gamma}(\cdot) is the randomized rounding, 𝒩ℤsubscript𝒩ℤ\mathcal{N}_{\mathbb{Z}} is the discrete Gaussian noise, and M[−r,r]​(⋅)subscript𝑀𝑟𝑟⋅M_{[-r,r]}(\cdot) is the module clipping (details can be found in Kairouz et al. (2021a)).

Now, we can write the left-hand side of (13) as

∥S⊺​(μ^y−1n​∑iyi)m∥∞=∥S⊺​U⊺​(z^−z~+z~−z)m∥∞≤∥S⊺​U⊺​(z^−z~)m∥∞⏟(1): module error+∥S⊺​U⊺​(z~−z)m∥∞⏟(2): rounding error.subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑆⊺subscript^𝜇𝑦1𝑛subscript𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑚subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑆⊺superscript𝑈⊺^𝑧~𝑧~𝑧𝑧𝑚subscript⏟subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑆⊺superscript𝑈⊺^𝑧~𝑧𝑚(1): module errorsubscript⏟subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑆⊺superscript𝑈⊺~𝑧𝑧𝑚(2): rounding error\left\lVert\frac{S^{\intercal}\left(\hat{\mu}_{y}-\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i}y_{i}\right)}{m}\right\rVert_{\infty}=\left\lVert\frac{S^{\intercal}U^{\intercal}\left(\hat{z}-\tilde{z}+\tilde{z}-z\right)}{m}\right\rVert_{\infty}\leq\underbrace{\left\lVert\frac{S^{\intercal}U^{\intercal}\left(\hat{z}-\tilde{z}\right)}{m}\right\rVert_{\infty}}_{\text{(1): module error}}+\underbrace{\left\lVert\frac{S^{\intercal}U^{\intercal}\left(\tilde{z}-z\right)}{m}\right\rVert_{\infty}}_{\text{(2): rounding error}}.

Define S′≜S⊺​U⊺m≜superscript𝑆′superscript𝑆⊺superscript𝑈⊺𝑚S^{\prime}\triangleq\frac{S^{\intercal}U^{\intercal}}{\sqrt{m}} and let Si′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑖S^{\prime}_{i} be the i𝑖i-th row of S′superscript𝑆′S^{\prime} for all i=1,…,d𝑖1…𝑑i=1,...,d. Now we bound (1) and (2) separately.

Bounding the module error

Observe that since ∥y∥22≤c′⁣2subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑦22superscript𝑐′2\left\lVert y\right\rVert^{2}_{2}\leq c^{\prime 2}, by Lemma 30 in Kairouz et al. (2021a) we have

∀t∈ℝ​∀j∈[m]​𝔼​[exp⁡(t​zj)]=𝔼​[exp⁡(t​(U​n​μy)j)]≤exp⁡(t2​n2​c′⁣22​m).for-all𝑡ℝfor-all𝑗delimited-[]𝑚𝔼delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝑧𝑗𝔼delimited-[]𝑡subscript𝑈𝑛subscript𝜇𝑦𝑗superscript𝑡2superscript𝑛2superscript𝑐′22𝑚\forall t\in\mathbb{R}\forall j\in[m]\,\mathbb{E}\left[\exp\left(tz_{j}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\exp\left(t\left(Un\mu_{y}\right)_{j}\right)\right]\leq\exp\left(\frac{t^{2}n^{2}c^{\prime 2}}{2m}\right).

Applying the union bound and the Chernoff’s bound yields

ℙ​{maxj=1,…,m⁡|zj|>2​n2​c′⁣2m​(log⁡m+log⁡(8δ))}≤δ4,ℙsubscript𝑗1…𝑚subscript𝑧𝑗2superscript𝑛2superscript𝑐′2𝑚𝑚8𝛿𝛿4\mathbb{P}\left\{\max_{j=1,...,m}\left\lvert z_{j}\right\rvert>\sqrt{2\frac{n^{2}c^{\prime 2}}{m}\left(\log m+\log\left(\frac{8}{\delta}\right)\right)}\right\}\leq\frac{\delta}{4}, (16)

where the randomness is over the random rotational matrix U𝑈U.

On the other hand, from Proposition 26, we have

𝔼​[exp⁡(t​(n​z~j−n​zj))]≤exp⁡(n​t2​(γ2+4​σ2)8)(1−β)n.𝔼delimited-[]𝑡𝑛subscript~𝑧𝑗𝑛subscript𝑧𝑗𝑛superscript𝑡2superscript𝛾24superscript𝜎28superscript1𝛽𝑛\mathbb{E}\left[\exp\left(t\left(n\tilde{z}_{j}-nz_{j}\right)\right)\right]\leq\frac{\exp\left(\frac{nt^{2}\left(\gamma^{2}+4\sigma^{2}\right)}{8}\right)}{\left(1-\beta\right)^{n}}.

Applying the Markov’s inequality and the union bound, we obtain

ℙ​{maxj∈[m]⁡|n​z~j−n​zj|≥t}≤m(1−β)n​exp⁡(−2​t2n​γ2+4​δ2).ℙsubscript𝑗delimited-[]𝑚𝑛subscript~𝑧𝑗𝑛subscript𝑧𝑗𝑡𝑚superscript1𝛽𝑛2superscript𝑡2𝑛superscript𝛾24superscript𝛿2\mathbb{P}\left\{\max_{j\in[m]}\left\lvert n\tilde{z}_{j}-nz_{j}\right\rvert\geq t\right\}\leq\frac{m}{(1-\beta)^{n}}\exp\left(-\frac{2t^{2}}{n\gamma^{2}+4\delta^{2}}\right).

Thus picking t=n​(γ2+4​σ2)2​(log⁡(1(1−β)n)+log⁡(4δ))𝑡𝑛superscript𝛾24superscript𝜎221superscript1𝛽𝑛4𝛿t=\sqrt{\frac{n\left(\gamma^{2}+4\sigma^{2}\right)}{2}\left(\log\left(\frac{1}{(1-\beta)^{n}}\right)+\log\left(\frac{4}{\delta}\right)\right)} yields

ℙ​{maxj∈[m]⁡|n​z~j−n​zj|≥n​(γ2+4​σ2)2​(log⁡(1(1−β)n)+log⁡(4δ))}≤δ4.ℙsubscript𝑗delimited-[]𝑚𝑛subscript~𝑧𝑗𝑛subscript𝑧𝑗𝑛superscript𝛾24superscript𝜎221superscript1𝛽𝑛4𝛿𝛿4\mathbb{P}\left\{\max_{j\in[m]}\left\lvert n\tilde{z}_{j}-nz_{j}\right\rvert\geq\sqrt{\frac{n\left(\gamma^{2}+4\sigma^{2}\right)}{2}\left(\log\left(\frac{1}{(1-\beta)^{n}}\right)+\log\left(\frac{4}{\delta}\right)\right)}\right\}\leq\frac{\delta}{4}. (17)

Putting (16) and (17) together, we arrive at

ℙ​{maxj∈[m]⁡|z~j|≥(n​(γ2+4​σ2)+4​n2​c′⁣2m)​(log⁡m+log⁡(1(1−β)n)+log⁡(8δ))}≤δ2,ℙsubscript𝑗delimited-[]𝑚subscript~𝑧𝑗𝑛superscript𝛾24superscript𝜎24superscript𝑛2superscript𝑐′2𝑚𝑚1superscript1𝛽𝑛8𝛿𝛿2\mathbb{P}\left\{\max_{j\in[m]}\left\lvert\tilde{z}_{j}\right\rvert\geq\sqrt{\left(n\left(\gamma^{2}+4\sigma^{2}\right)+\frac{4n^{2}c^{\prime 2}}{m}\right)\left(\log m+\log\left(\frac{1}{(1-\beta)^{n}}\right)+\log\left(\frac{8}{\delta}\right)\right)}\right\}\leq\frac{\delta}{2}, (18)

where we use the fact that a+b≤2​(a+b)𝑎𝑏2𝑎𝑏\sqrt{a}+\sqrt{b}\leq\sqrt{2(a+b)} and the union bound.

Finally, observe that as long as ∥z~∥∞≤rsubscriptdelimited-∥∥~𝑧𝑟\left\lVert\tilde{z}\right\rVert_{\infty}\leq r, z^≜M[−r,r]​(z~)=z~≜^𝑧subscript𝑀𝑟𝑟~𝑧~𝑧\hat{z}\triangleq M_{[-r,r]}(\tilde{z})=\tilde{z}. Thus by picking

r≜(n​(γ2+4​σ2)+4​n2​c′⁣2m)​(log⁡m+log⁡(1(1−β)n)+log⁡(8δ)),≜𝑟𝑛superscript𝛾24superscript𝜎24superscript𝑛2superscript𝑐′2𝑚𝑚1superscript1𝛽𝑛8𝛿r\triangleq\sqrt{\left(n\left(\gamma^{2}+4\sigma^{2}\right)+\frac{4n^{2}c^{\prime 2}}{m}\right)\left(\log m+\log\left(\frac{1}{(1-\beta)^{n}}\right)+\log\left(\frac{8}{\delta}\right)\right)},

we have

ℙ​{∥S⊺​U⊺​(z^−z~)m∥∞>0}≤δ2.ℙsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑆⊺superscript𝑈⊺^𝑧~𝑧𝑚0𝛿2\mathbb{P}\left\{\left\lVert\frac{S^{\intercal}U^{\intercal}\left(\hat{z}-\tilde{z}\right)}{m}\right\rVert_{\infty}>0\right\}\leq\frac{\delta}{2}.

Bounding the module error

First notice that

ℙ​{∥S⊺​U⊺​(n​z^−n​z~)m∥∞≥t}ℙsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑆⊺superscript𝑈⊺𝑛^𝑧𝑛~𝑧𝑚𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left\{\left\lVert\frac{S^{\intercal}U^{\intercal}\left(n\hat{z}-n\tilde{z}\right)}{m}\right\rVert_{\infty}\geq t\right\} =ℙ​{maxi∈[d]⁡⟨Si′,(n​z~−n​z)⟩≥t}+ℙ​{maxi∈[d]−⟨Si′,(n​z~−n​z)⟩≥t}absentℙsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑖𝑛~𝑧𝑛𝑧𝑡ℙsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑖𝑛~𝑧𝑛𝑧𝑡\displaystyle=\mathbb{P}\left\{\max_{i\in[d]}\langle S^{\prime}_{i},(n\tilde{z}-nz)\rangle\geq t\right\}+\mathbb{P}\left\{\max_{i\in[d]}-\langle S^{\prime}_{i},(n\tilde{z}-nz)\rangle\geq t\right\}

ℙ​{maxi∈[d]⁡⟨Si′,(n​z~−n​z)⟩≥t}ℙsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑖𝑛~𝑧𝑛𝑧𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left\{\max_{i\in[d]}\langle S^{\prime}_{i},(n\tilde{z}-nz)\rangle\geq t\right\} ≤∑i∈[d]ℙ​{exp⁡(⟨λ​Si′,n​z−n​z~⟩)≥exp⁡(λ​t)}absentsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑑ℙ𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑖𝑛𝑧𝑛~𝑧𝜆𝑡\displaystyle\leq\sum_{i\in[d]}\mathbb{P}\left\{\exp\left(\langle\lambda S^{\prime}_{i},nz-n\tilde{z}\rangle\right)\geq\exp\left(\lambda t\right)\right\}

On the other hand,

ℙ​{maxi∈[d]−⟨Si′,(n​z~−n​z)⟩≥t}ℙsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑑subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑖𝑛~𝑧𝑛𝑧𝑡\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left\{\max_{i\in[d]}-\langle S^{\prime}_{i},(n\tilde{z}-nz)\rangle\geq t\right\} ≤∑i∈[d]ℙ​{exp⁡(⟨−λ​Si′,n​z−n​z~⟩)≥exp⁡(λ​t)}absentsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑑ℙ𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑖𝑛𝑧𝑛~𝑧𝜆𝑡\displaystyle\leq\sum_{i\in[d]}\mathbb{P}\left\{\exp\left(\langle-\lambda S^{\prime}_{i},nz-n\tilde{z}\rangle\right)\geq\exp\left(\lambda t\right)\right\}

Thus picking

t=n​(log⁡(d(1−β)n+log⁡(4δ))​(γ2+4​σ28)​(maxi=1,…,d∥Si∥22m))t=\sqrt{n\left(\log\left(\frac{d}{(1-\beta)^{n}}+\log\left(\frac{4}{\delta}\right)\right)\left(\frac{\gamma^{2}+4\sigma^{2}}{8}\right)\left(\frac{\max_{i=1,...,d}\left\lVert S_{i}\right\rVert^{2}_{2}}{m}\right)\right)}

yields

ℙ​{∥S⊺​U⊺​(n​z^−n​z~)m∥∞≥t}=ℙ​{∥S⊺​U⊺​(z^−z~)m∥∞≥t/n}≤δ2.ℙsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑆⊺superscript𝑈⊺𝑛^𝑧𝑛~𝑧𝑚𝑡ℙsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑆⊺superscript𝑈⊺^𝑧~𝑧𝑚𝑡𝑛𝛿2\mathbb{P}\left\{\left\lVert\frac{S^{\intercal}U^{\intercal}\left(n\hat{z}-n\tilde{z}\right)}{m}\right\rVert_{\infty}\geq t\right\}=\mathbb{P}\left\{\left\lVert\frac{S^{\intercal}U^{\intercal}\left(\hat{z}-\tilde{z}\right)}{m}\right\rVert_{\infty}\geq t/n\right\}\leq\frac{\delta}{2}.
